Trump says Ukraine deal closer than ever, but no apparent breakthrough after talks
subhead: A day after Russia unleashed major new attacks on residential areas of Kyiv, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky visited the US president in Mar-a-Lago. Zelensky said that the peace framework laid out by Trump was '90% agreed' and that he and European leaders could return to Washington for talks with Trump in January.

Europe's dramatic decline in pharmaceutical production threatens health sovereignty
subhead: The rise of China and India, combined with protectionist pressure from the Trump administration, is redrawing the global map of the pharmaceutical industry. The Europe-wide deindustrialization that began in the 2000s is now accelerating.

title: 2025: A bleak year for jobs in the telecom sector in Europe and the US
subhead: Telecom operators and equipment manufacturers have cut tens of thousands of jobs. Fierce competition, difficulties in making 5G profitable, and the rapid digitalization of roles in the sector are driving the trend.

title: 'The Beatles have become an inexhaustible source of nostalgia-fueled products'
subhead: Thomas Sotinel examines the thriving business that still surrounds the 'Fab Four' and their legend, more than five decades after the group's official break-up.

title: The Orient Express pulls up in Paris: An opulent journey into the 1920s
subhead: The legendary luxury train is making a stop at Paris's Musée des Arts Décoratifs until spring. As part of the major exhibition dedicated to the centenary of Art Deco, three life-size mock-ups of the new Orient Express, set to return to service soon, are on display.

Brigitte Bardot's 30 years of sympathy for the far right
subhead: Convicted five times for racist remarks, the actress – whose foundation announced her death on Sunday, December 28 – remained one of the only French celebrities to openly embrace far-right views.

title: How dining etiquette reveals social divides among young people
subhead: Choosing a natural wine, slicing comté cheese the 'right' way, opening an oyster: For young people lacking the right social codes, embarrassment at the table is often inevitable.

title: Six thousand new perfumes in 2025: Why manufacturers are flooding the market
subhead: The perfume sector is experiencing a global consumption revolution: Young people are collecting bottles, and Chinese consumers are buying more and more. With L'Oréal leading the way, perfume has become the main sector driving the cosmetics industry.
